comments.commentBody: So what's the deal !  It's New York !! if not here where on the earth are you going to enjoy ??

Enjoy!!! NYC has plenty of free city pools, though they do fill up and time is limited, many inexpensive neighborhood pools to join, or the subway to the beach. Not the same as hopping upstairs for a quick jaunt, but still, I'd rather have NYC outside my door :-)
That Z-shaped rental has a pool, just somehow not in that shot. For the others, care to fill a wading pool?
And "Game of Thrones" was originally published in 1996, so Ned Stark's death probably wasn't a big shock to Sean Bean--who is notorious for playing characters who die, anyhow.
If a majority of shareholders vote to ban abortifacient payments, then wouldn't that settle it, too?
Yes .... sounds like any other democracy where numerous and disparate voters need to be organized.
If the Supreme Court rules that corporations have the option to ban abortifacient payments than shareholders have the option to vote to ban or allow such payments.

Of course shareholders have the right to prohibit the corporation they own from channeling resources to political campaigns. If a majority of shareholders so vote then the issue is settled, no corporate campaign contributions.
"Swell" is slang?  Old-fashioned?  No, the old-fashioned meaning is the nominative from the twenties.

I went to the 2005 column you reference. It is instructive to note that you have quoted the part about Krugman in full. So Okrent give no examples, no data amd no references for his assertion. Contrast that with this brief post of Krugman's.

As to the plot, look at what the y-axis measures. It is not total jobs. It appears to the the ratio of the number of people working divided by the number of people working in 2008. So it is independent of population.

Of course, if you read that section of his column, you'll note that the Public Editor was extremely smug about not giving Prof. Krugman a chance to reply. It was the last column of his term as P.E., and then he was out the door.

I wouldn't put too much credence in it.

That's an interesting read; he - Daniel Okrent - actually takes everybody to task including himself.  Thanks for the link.  The problem Prof Krugman faces in his columns and blogs, but especially the columns, is that there is only so much room and there is an infinite supply of data.  It isn't cherry picking to limit the number of sources one can cite, especially in an 800 word column.  But he always links to his sources so the industrious reader can check his facts.  The reader is also left to believe what he wants to believe, even when the facts in evidence stronly support PK's conclusions, and sometimes it doesn't take much to refute a conclusion.  It's worth reminding ourselves once in a while that, in any real sense, whatever we - the commenters - know about economics, Paul Krugman knows more.

Everyone cherry picks data to bolster her/his argument. Present company included.

From the public editor of the New York Times :
"Op-Ed columnist Paul Krugman has the disturbing habit of shaping, slicing and selectively citing numbers in a fashion that pleases his acolytes but leaves him open to substantive assaults"

http://www.nytimes.com/2005/05/22/weekinreview/22okrent.html

As to the plot, it needes to be adjusted for population growth to paint a relevant picture of employment. If adjusted, it shows that job creation in Texas exceeded population growth, NY kept with it and CA and FL now have less jobs per population than in 2007.
Never liked Red Smith's and his cohort's ad hominem style.  Joe Durso writing about real baseball is for me.

Very interesting read. Yoo, like Moon, seems to know how to use religions to enrich their families. Several sneaky people just know how to fool many stupid followers. In countries where religious organizations enjoy tax exemptions, many use religions to benefit themselves at the expense of their countries. the ideology of so called free market capitalism is itself a badly listing ship; will we be surprised when it capsizes because of severe overloading to squeeze every last cent out of every last voyage at the expense of innocent souls aboard simply for the extra gain of its owners?

YA, I am a Caucasian American who is well aware of the tradition of suicide in Japan resulting from personal or family shame (business failures, inability to pass university entrance exams etc.) As you know, there are even famous locations for committing suicide in Japan (forest of death at Aokigahara (青木ヶ原), suicide cliffs at Tōjinbō (東尋坊).

Based on reports, Mr. Yoo was apparently a lifelong scam artist, fraudster and criminal. We are talking about a narcissist and psychopath. He displayed no honor in life or death. In fact, the "death" is thought to be yet another fraud. Mr. Yoo is likely living in a guarded compound in the same manner as Osama bin Laden.

Speaking of atonement, did Asahara Shoko (麻原 彰晃) ever accept responsibility for the thousands of casualties resulting from the sarin gas attacks in Matsumoto and Tokyo 20 years ago? Perhaps you can explain this for us somewhat dense Americans.

"honorable"??!! You are kidding right?!

His dead body does nothing --NOTHING -- for the victims' families. What would have been more "honorable" would have been for him to turn over ALL of his fortune (incl. those abroad) to the families of the victims and to charities. Then, turn himself and his sons -- including the one in the US -- in to the authorities to accept punishment. This, would have been more "honorable".

Japanese tradition or not, the practice of "honorable death" is actually not "honorable" at all. In fact, it is cowardly.

Indeed, cowardly by American sensibilities isn't it? But at least they show their 'honour' by putting an end to themselves which is in their native tradition. For those comments that pour scorn on this, just remember that they should be judged by their their standards and not ours, which is not understood by Americans. The latter seem to think that everyone in the world should conform to their code of behavioiur, which incidently, is not a standard to be emulated.

I'll say this for him, at least he took the honourable way out by committing suicide; surely this would at least atone for the unfortunate deaths that he was responsible for on that dreadful day of days.

We are animals.  The thing that distinguishes us from other animals is our thinking, communication and social skills.  Capitalism pitches alot of that in favor of power.  It's idiotic, but that's what capitalism is:  A lowest common denominator method of power seeking and resource apportionment.  Representative governments could and should be better, but people are very greedy and jealous (and don't follow rules well).

"How many of the past 21 days did you see the TdF mentioned on ESPN? Or in the NYT? Especially in the NYT where this is probably the most space the entire race has received. How many hours of coverage did NBC give the race? Televised coverage of cycling is at an all time low in the past 25 years."

Talk about nonsense. There was a dropoff in coverage and viewership in the US when all-American boy wonder Armstrong retired. That was followed by a really massive dropoff when Armstrong was revealed. The sport is still suffering from the fallout.

The TCF was discontinued while the sport was still popular with Armstrong. Nobody is suggesting that women join the Tour de France: Elite category professional women may be faster than non-Elite men, but they are slower than Elite men. They deserve their own race. There used to be one, and it was a great, great race.

Ummm no
http://observer.theguardian.com/osm/story/0,,543962,00.html

Thank you, these false dramas are now too common now in the NYT. We get enough of these in our local papers. That being said, here I am dragged into this fallacy of an argument--professional sports are staged performance about making a buck... plain and simple. If anyone is "excluded" its simply because nobody has figured out how to make money off of them.

This is the typical nonsense that NYT has lowered itself to to create the drama it feels is needed to attract the diminishing intelligence level of the American public. Anyone who follows and understands the sport of cycling knows it is all about diminishing resources, sponsorships and tv exposure.  How many of the past 21 days did you see the TdF mentioned on ESPN?  Or in the NYT?  Especially in the NYT where this is probably the most space the entire race has received. How many hours of coverage did NBC give the race?  Televised coverage of cycling is at an all time low in the past 25 years. Print coverage is non existant. And this article questions why women dont have their own tour or why they arent included in the mens tour?  Some one here, either editor, author or both, or NYT, is entirely clueless. When women can compete at a high level with the men over a gruelling 9 month season, the sport would embrace them. And I wiould love to watch them. I warch womens cycling now.  Unfortunately, that day is not today. I am shocked this article isnt asking why wnba women are exluded from the nba, or from major league baseball, or why dont women regularly compete against men in golf or tennis.  By the way, why are their seperate "ladies tees" in golf?   This is just another example of NYT rabble rousing to create interest. Please, stop lowering yourself to this level. I remember when NYT was the pinnacle of journalism. Now, welcome to the same level as daily news and ny post

You have a major point. I decided a long time ago that I simply would never watch sports in which women didn't play for equal fame and money. And at 47, I'm more athletic than by far the vast majority of men half my age. And coming back to cycling. (Bought a 30-year-old steel crit bike for a song because I knew it would be a blast to ride and I wouldn't have a lot of money in it if I decided I didn't want to do it after all.)

I agree. The tycoon was basically hunted down to death. The entire S Korean Coast Guard was DISMANTLED and became a department of the national police. That's like US Financial market regulators being stripped of their seniority and becoming part of the FBI, not Treasury dept, for not catching the financial meltdown.

Yes there's corruption in S Korea but same in US. It's even glamorized as lobbyists and K-street. But the difference is in S Koreas, ones responsible were kicked out the door and hunted down.

Before Americans point fingers at the incident to mock, there's somethings we could learn.
In principle I agree, but at the same time our deregulatory fiascoes have not been so dramatic (and tragic). 300 school children, all at once, is a lot to not have some heads rolling.

On the face of this tragedy how telling that a society, that its government, and that Mr. Yoo and his familiy could not escape and actually believed in something that seems lacking in the West: Responsibility.

What a difference --yes, corporate malfeasance occurred, but in South Korea there was no palling around to corporations and their above-the-law status (unless, of course, the law benefits them).

Nor did South Koreans, or Mr. Yoo himself were hoodwinked into owners and managers not being responsible nor deserving of punishment or of profound shame.

Compare this to our sorry state: A pharmacy murders its patients by preparing mold and bacteria spine compounds and its owners remain free, or lawyers and executives killed so many GM customers it is difficult to count, and their punishment is retirement, some financiers destroy the wealth of millions, and not a single name has been prosecuted, etc., etc. and etc.

South Korea might understandably feel bowed by the ferry disaster, but, at the end of the day, they can stand proud compared to the sorry state of amorality and impunity rampant in America.

All readers of this piece on the business must not remember the role of the bungling local government in the bizarre failure to rescue the victims of the disaster. More South Koreans find it more unsettling because they see in it some machination with a political motive.

Kudos to the journalists on their fantastic reporting.

I'd be willing to bet that this is far from the only business family engaged in this type of behavior in S. Korea. All the murky stories that one has heard about Samsung in the press leads me to hope that the reporters will dig into that Chaebol as well.

"The obsession over wealth and physical beauty, conspicuous consumption and global rankings, and contempt for the poor and the unfortunate have corroded the national fabric."

Sounds like you just described the state of the USA. Does GM hiding faults in its cars for decades while innocents died sound familiar to you? Both countries need serious reform.
Also the bizarre obsession of South Korean society with the christian religion.

The underbelly of the "Miracle on the Han River" has been the relentless greed and corruption within South Korean society. While a lot of ink has been spilled over bureaucratic and political aspects of Sewol incident, there needs to be greater introspection on the culture of South Korea. The obsession over wealth and physical beauty, conspicuous consumption and global rankings, and contempt for the poor and the unfortunate have corroded the national fabric. While ranting about Dokdo Island and Japanese war crimes is easy, the hard work of building a more humane, just, and righteous Korea is urgently needed. In South Korea today, connections win out over merit, bribes and favors are expected, and pretty and handsome trump hard working and smart.
A lesson for America's amen corner of deregulators.

What's ironic is that if Yoo had never been found out, his descendants would undoubtedly have entered the highest precincts of society in Seoul, New York and Paris. As Balzac so memorably put it, "All great fortunes begin with a crime."

He reminds me of John Hodgman's "Deranged Millionaire."
http://thedailyshow.cc.com/videos/8ecahg/a-deranged-millionaire-shrugs
Yes, but he had to Murder HOW many to find it (justice)?

A crook and a scam artist, to say the least, but an extremely stupid one. He decks out a ferry boat with a marble art gallery that makes it top-heavy?

Then doesn't train the crew that sails his floating gallery, then overloads it with too many passengers who could take a ferry to get somewhere and could care less about art, putting his art gallery at risk in the process.

And if that weren't crazy enough, he organizes a church as another way of fleecing people?

Okay, maybe that's one of the more tradition ways of ripping people off, but with the exception of Noah, boats and religion usually don't get intertwined like this maniac did it.

It just goes to prove that there's no correlation whatsoever between wealth and brains. Reading that he's died after leading a life of such conniving and scheming people out of their lives and money comes more as a relief rather than a tragedy, considering he did it to himself with no one else to blame.

Maybe there is real justice in this world after all.

Christianity in Korea, brought over by the Americans during the war - Protestant bibles are in English (!) and in Korean on the facing page - never went through a period of reform but alloyed instantly with the pagan I-give-an-offering-and-thus-will-get-a-good-harvest. The Presbytarians (as cited in the article) also have Mega churches in Seoul's most coveted real estate with church leaders who don't learn any Greek or Hebrew living in unseemly luxury for the ground crew of a heavenly invisible friend, paid for by people who cannot afford it. So call it a cult if you must - it's really relative.
Geun-hye Park and her ultraconservative party have now gotten rid of a pawn prime minister and this church guy here (conspiracy minded Koreans want to see the DNA evidence it's really him - me too), all the while she has demonstrating family members of the high school kids who perished there arrested. We can certainly expect more great things of this dictator's daughter who is so incompetent that W would look intelligent next to her. If pressure keeps up, they might get rid of a high ranking Navy officer or two who botched the rescue. The officials who were (and I'm sure still are) bribed to look the other way and the parties that got money will go scot-free. The good thing that now keeps this vertically integrated Korean economy, politics and society from implosion - it wasn't anyone from the Samsung-, LG- or Hyundai- controlling families.

Virtually everything in this article has already been reported in the Korean press for months, in even more grotesque detail. There is very little here that the Koreans don't already know about through their media.

I hope this entire article is translated into Korean and published in Seoul.  It illustrates what happens in a society when anything can be manipulated through the abuse of power and money.  This stain affects all things, great and small and harms us when we least expect it.

The majority of rescues at sea involve removing passengers / crew from an exposed deck; rescuing people in the water or in life boats / rafts.  In this instance you have a structure that is not in the vertical, and partially underwater.  Now, you have entry ways that are submerged and overhead or down.  Imagine your home being tipped 60 degrees and partially underwater and a first responder trying to effect a rescue.  The article stated that the Korean Coast Guard were unable to hoist themselves up the smooth side of the ship.  The coast guard is a first responder.  Gaining entry, even with divers would involved going from space to space at "crawl" and hand searching.  If you have the opportunity, question a fire fighter about the difficulty of doing a search in a densly smoked filled structure.

You didn't read it carefully enough. The unfortunate students were told to stay in their cabins. When the rescuers got there, the cabins were already submerged. They would have need the strength of earth movers to part the waters enough to counter the enormous water pressure keeping the doors closed.

The coast guard has plenty of experience rescuing crew from sinking cargo ships and fishing boats. This incident was new, in that the ferry had a few hundred passengers. S Korea has not had such big ferry ship until around 10 years ago. Before, they were single or double deck with 100 or so passenger capacity.

Throughout this entire article, the part that struck me and stuck most in my mind and made me go back to reread was that the coast guard boat arrived and was unable to make an effective rescue. I honestly feel I must be missing something. The coast guard arrived unprepared to make a rescue. Say that a few times over and tell me what you come up with.

Andy,
